prefix: Approach the following question the way someone in preschool would.
solution: Since the ant starts at the top vertex, his next destination, vertex A, is equally likely to be any of the 4 vertices along the middle ring. Each of these vertices is adjacent to 4 other vertices, and since they are in the middle, exactly 1 of those 4 vertices is the bottom vertex. So, regardless of which intermediate vertex he goes to, the ant will end up at the bottom vertex with $\boxed{\frac{1}{4}}$ probability, by the symmetry of the 4 intermediate stages.
gpt_response:
Okie dokie! So an octahedron looks like this funny shape with eight faces. Imagine the ant starts at the tippy top and walks to one of the four corners. Let's call that vertex A. Then from there, the ant walks to one of the four corners again. We want to find the chance that the ant ends up at the bottom corner. 

Since the ant can walk to any of the four corners from vertex A, there are four possibilities. And since we want to know the probability that the ant ends up at the bottom corner, that's just one out of those four possibilities. So, the probability is 1 out of 4, which is the same as 1/4. Yippee!

Since the ant can walk to any of the four corners from vertex A, there are four possibilities. And since we want to know the probability that the ant ends up at the bottom corner, that's just one out of those four possibilities. So, the probability is 1 out of 4, which is the same as 1/4. Yippee!
